Disclaimer text delivered by COM (pollutant transfers)

The European Pollutant Release and Transfer Register is the first European wide register informing the public and policy makers about annual emissions from industrial activities and other diffuse sources in the Member States and EFTA countries.

The scope of E-PRTR is set by Annex I of the E-PRTR Regulation (EC) No 166/2006 which covers the main industrial and agricultural activities affecting pollution levels in Europe.

The register makes available annual data covering releases to air, water and soil and off site transfers of waste and waste water of about 24 000 large point sources across Europe.
It is possible to monitor and search emissions from an extensive list of 91 pollutants; data can be accessed both at aggregated and disaggregated level using map tools and queries.

E-PRTR contributes to public participation in environmental decision-making; the register implements at EU level (27 Member States of the European Union, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway) the UNECE PRTR Protocol to the Arhus Convention.

Legal Obligations

EU member states and EFTA countries report releases and transfers from all activities listed in Annex I of the E-PRTR Regulation (EC) No 166/2006. Those include installations that fall within the scope of the IPPC Directive (Directive 2008/1/EC), of the ETS Directive (Directive 2003/87/EC), and other plants covered by sectoral Directives.

The E-PRTR Regulation was adopted in response to the Protocol on Pollutant Release and Transfer Registers to the Convention on Access to Information, Public Participation in Decision-making and Access to Justice on Environmental Matters "the Aarhus Convention" issued by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UN-ECE). The EU is a signatory to the UN-ECE PRTR Protocol and therefore it is required to develop a European wide register.
The E-PRTR succeeds the European Pollutant Emission Register (EPER) under which data were reported for the years 2001 and 2004.


In accordance with the Aarhus Convention, the public should be granted access to E-PRTR data without an interest to be stated; the European Commission is responsible for providing direct electronic access and promoting understanding and using of the information contained in the register. The Commission is also responsible for including information on releases from diffuse sources, where available and already reported by the Member States.

The E-PRTR Regulation entered into force on the 24 February 2006. According to Article 5, operators of facilities that undertake one or more of the activities set out in Annex I to the E-PRTR Regulation are obliged, on an annual basis starting in 2007,to report specific information if the applicable capacity threshold(s), Annex I to the E-PRTR Regulation, and release threshold(s), Columns 1a, b, and c of the table set out in Annex II to the E-PRTR Regulation, and/or the applicable capacity threshold(s) and off-site transfer threshold(s) for pollutants in waste water, Column 1b of the table set out in Annex II to the E-PRTR Regulation, or for waste, 2 tons for hazardous waste or 2,000 tons for nonhazardous waste, are exceeded.


What is reported to the E-PRTR?
Annex I of the E-PRTR Regulation lists 65 activities. Annex I enables operators to identify whether they are affected by the associated reporting obligations. The activities are grouped in 9 activity sectors:

  • energy
  • production and processing of metals
  • mineral industry
  • chemical industry
  • waste and waste water management
  • paper and wood production and processing
  • intensive livestock production and aquaculture
  • animal and vegetable products from the food and beverage sector
  • other activities.

There is an obligation for the operator to report releases and off-site transfers if an activity specified in Annex I is carried out and the capacity threshold specified therein is exceeded.

For releases of pollutants to air, water and land and for off-site transfers of pollutants in waste water the corresponding threshold values are specified for each pollutant in Annex II of the E-PRTR Regulation. Annex II of the Regulation lists the 91 pollutants that are relevant for reporting under the E-PRTR. The pollutants are specified by a consecutive number, the CAS number, where available, and the name of the pollutant.

For off-site transfers of waste the threshold values are 2 tonnes per year for hazardous waste and 2,000 tonnes per year for non-hazardous waste.

Pollutant reporting thresholds are set to collect 90% of the total mass emission from PRTR regulated industrial sources of a specified pollutant.

The full dataset of E-PRTR is hosted by the European Environment Agency (EEA) in its Data Service. The EEA Data service provides access to databases generated under several reporting mechanisms such as E-PRTR...

The following link provides you access to the E-PRTR dataset:
http://dataservice.eea.europa.eu/dataservice/available2.asp?type=findkeyword&theme=air%20emissions

Article 14 of the E-PRTR Regulation provides that the European Commission shall draw up a guidance document supporting the implementation of the E-PRTR. Such a document was developed in May 2006.

The document provides guidance on the various reporting processes as set out in the
E-PRTR Regulation.

The Guidance document is available here for download as word and PDF file (approximately 1,7Mb):
http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/pollutants/stationary/eper/index.htm

An off-site transfer of waste means the movement beyond the boundaries of a facility of waste destined for disposal or recovery.

Thresholds off-site transfers of waste
HW 2 tonnes/year
Non-HW 2.000 tonnes/year

Operators shall report off-site transfers of

  • hazardous waste (HW), exceeding 2 tonnes per year
  • non hazardous waste (non-HW), exceeding 2 000 tonnes per year

for any operations of recovery or disposal with the exception of the disposal operations of land treatment and deep injection, as these have to be reported as releases to land.

  • 'Waste' means any substance or object as defined in Article 1(a) of Council Directive 75/442/EEC on waste of 15 July 1975
  • 'Hazardous waste' means any substance or object as defined in Article 1(4) of Council Directive 91/689/EEC on hazardous waste of 12 December 1991
  • Non hazardous waste' means any waste which is not 'Hazardous waste'

All data are expressed in tonnes/year of (normal) wet waste and with three significant digits.

With respect to the threshold value, the sum of waste transferred off-site is relevant, irrespective of whether it is treated within the country or it is transferred to another country or whether it is disposed of or recovered.

The operator indicates whether the waste is destined for recovery ("R") or for disposal ("D"). If the waste is destined for waste treatment that includes both recovery and disposal operations (e.g. sorting), the treatment operation (R or D) for which more than 50% of the waste is destined should be reported. In those rare cases where the facility is not able to trace whether more than 50% of the waste is disposed or recovered, then code "D" is used.

All PRTR data reported by operators appears on the web-site with the exception of confidential data. Information that is classified confidential by the competent authorities in accordance with Article 11 of the E-PRTR Regulation is not transmitted to E-PRTR.

In general the grounds for confidentiality claims are listed in Article 4(2) of Directive 2003/4/EC on public access to environmental information.  Data related to the identification of a facility can be kept confidential only if the name and the address of the facility are of a natural person. In such cases the geographical coordinates of the facility shall be reported.

An exception applies to emissions/releases and off-site transfers of pollutants in waste water. In case of confidentiality, the name of the pollutant is replaced by the name of a pollutant group while the method of measurement/calculation is not reported.

Member States may refuse disclosure of environmental information on emissions/releases and off-site transfers in waste water if they would adversely affect:

  • International relations, public security or national defence - Article 4(2)(b)
  • The course of Justice- Article 4(2)(c)
  • Intellectual property rights- Article 4(2)(e)

This page presents the statistics on confidentiality and the reason for not disclosing data to E-PRTR provided by the reporting countries.

In case of confidentiality, the name of the pollutant is replaced by the name of a pollutant group while the method of measurement/calculation is not reported. The reason given for confidentiality claims is presented in the confidentiality sheet.

Released quantities of the PRTR facilities are always reported. However due to confidentiality claims, the total emissions of single pollutants transferred off-site by PRTR activities might be different from the aggregated data presented in the register. Only aggregated data on transfers of pollutants group include all the emissions actually reported to E-PRTR.

Member States may refuse disclosure of environmental information on pollutant transfers if they would adversely affect:
  • International relations, public security or national defence - Article 4(2)(b)
  • The course of Justice- Article 4(2)(c)
  • Intellectual property rights- Article 4(2)(e)

This page presents the statistics on confidentiality and the reason for not disclosing data to E-PRTR provided by the reporting countries.

In case of confidentiality, the name of the pollutant is replaced by the name of a pollutant group while the method of measurement/calculation of the emission release is not reported. The reason given for confidentiality claims is presented in the confidentiality sheet.

Released quantities of the PRTR facilities are always reported. However due to confidentiality claims, the total emissions of single pollutants released in the environment by PRTR activities might be different from the aggregated data presented in the register. Only aggregated data on emissions of pollutants group include all the emissions actually reported to E-PRTR.

Member States may refuse disclosure of environmental information on emission and release if they would adversely affect:
  • International relations, public security or national defence - Article 4(2)(b)
  • The course of Justice- Article 4(2)(c)
  • Intellectual property rights- Article 4(2)(e)

This page presents the statistics on confidentiality and the reason for not disclosing data to E-PRTR provided by the reporting countries.

In general the grounds for confidentiality claims are listed in Article 4(2) of Directive 2003/4/EC on public access to environmental information.  The reason given for confidentiality claims is presented in the confidentiality sheet. Geographical coordinates of the facility are always to be reported.

In case of confidentiality, if the waste transfer quantity is not reported, the method shall be withheld too. The total amount of waste transferred off-site by PRTR activities might be affected by confidentiality claims.

The E-PRTR Regulation establishes that releases of pollutants from diffuse sources, where available, must be part of the E-PRTR inventory. Specific provisions on this subject are set out in Article 8 of the E-PRTR Regulation.

Diffuse sources means the many smaller or scattered sources from which pollutants may be released to land, air or water, whose combined impact on those media may be significant and for which it is impractical to collect reports from each individual source. Sectors such as road traffic, shipping, aviation, certain agricultural activities, domestic heating, etc., fall under this definition.

The Commission and the EEA are working to fulfil these needs and make available a set of GIS layers containing valuable information on releases from diffuse sources. A specific study on "releases into air" will be undertaken along 2010. The Commission, in close cooperation with the EEA, will follow-up possible upgrades on the information available in the field of releases into water systems.

For the moment, the website, presents the outcome of previous studies linked to diffuse emission into water as well as links to background information on the subject.

• Diffuse releases into water

• Diffuse releases into Air (to be developed along 2010)

• Background information on diffuse releases
For the moment, the website, only presents diffuse emissions into water.

Agricultural nutrient emissions

Information from a number of sources has been used: agricultural nutrient emissions information provided via the EEA’s State of the Environment (SoE) test data exchange, WFD Article 5 reports, International River Basin Commissions reports, National Environment Agency websites and research papers.

Where more than one information source was available for the same RBD, the most recent one was preferred. The periods reported differ between sources, the oldest data covering 1986-92, the newest data from 2006. Some data represent single years, whilst other data represent an average over a number of years (typically 3-5 years).

Corine land Cover 2000

CLC2000 database version 9/2007

EU River Basin Districts (RBD)

The map was created before the publication of a first official version of the European RBD. Therefore a non-standard version of the RBD layer was used. For future updates of the map, the most recent RBD layer available at that point in time will be used to ensure a maximum consistency between the existing European datasets.

Detailed information concerning the datasets used is provided in the ETC/ACC report which is available here. In case you do not have access to the protected website please contact European Topic Centre for Water (ETC/W).

The map shows the agricultural N contribution to surface water in river basins of the EU per hectare of agricultural land area in the river basin district (RBD), where this information was available during first half of 2008.

The nitrogen losses are expressed in kg N per hectare agricultural land in a river basin district (RBD) per year.

GIS overlay

Agricultural nutrient emissions per river basin district (RBD) were distributed over the agricultural area of the RBD using a GIS overlay technique. The land cover distribution within each RBD was calculated by overlaying the river basin district map with the CORINE land cover map.

Comparability

The agricultural nutrient emissions data stem from a range of different sources and relate to different years and/or averaging periods. Some data specify the load at the outlet of the catchment (mouth), some at the edge of the streams (edge). Normally the estimates at the mouth of the basin are lower than at the edge of stream because some nutrient retention takes place along the stream systems.

Considerable spatial variation in emissions is apparent. The reasons for the differences are:

  1. The percentage of agriculture in the basin. RBDs with a low percentage of agricultural land tend to have lower agricultural emissions per ha of catchment than RBDs with a high percentage of agricultural land.
  2. The variation in the type and management of agriculture across Europe.
  3. The year or years over which emissions have been calculated will also have a strong influence, due to hydrological variation. N-emission is generally higher in years with high rainfall.
  4. The method used to estimate the total agricultural load. As an example, some countries deduct a “background load” from the agricultural emissions, while others do not, but there are also other differences,
  5. The retention in the basins, which depends on geology and hydrology.

The applied methodology is described in detail in the ETC/ACC report which is available here. In case you do not have access to the protected website please contact European Topic Centre for Water (ETC/W).
